Improve the token server to refresh tokens and enforce backoff (#42)

Improve the token server so that it refreshes tokens and enforces backoff.

It uses a RefCell<> to manage the state (so that we don't need to declare
the functions which use the context as mutable) and uses an Enum and simple
state machine to try and get into a state where a token is available.

Needs tests, but I'm not sure how to add them (and it didn't come with tests
in the first place which I could build from)

It introduces a new StorageResetError, which could also be used in the future
if we detect a change to the syncID, and changes BackoffError to take a
SystemTime instead of an f64.

Port the Sync setup state machine from iOS.

This replaces `remote_setup` with a more explicit state machine that
handles fetching `meta/global` and `crypto/keys`, and determining
which engines need to be enabled, disabled, or reset. Unlike iOS,
we don't use a persistent "scratchpad"; `GlobalState` is in-memory
only for now.

Split `Sync15Service` into `Sync15StorageClient` and `GlobalState`.

* `Sync15StorageClient` is a basic wrapper around `reqwest::Client`
  that makes authenticated requests to, and decodes responses from, the
  storage node. The client doesn't hold any state, except for the
  current server time.
* `GlobalState` holds all state that should be persisted across syncs.
  This state is updated by the setup state machine, which is introduced
  in the next commit.

Building everything for three architectures just takes a long time --
15 minutes per architecture or more.

I investigated speeding this up, and I conclude that compiling the
architectures in parallel is both work (you need to work around cargo
a little bit, and you need to use a Make jobserver to limit the total
thread pool) and doesn't pay off (I witnessed only about a 5-10%
speed-up locally).  My guess is that it pays off even less in AWS,
where IO throughput is relatively low and context switching relatively
more expensive.

Build FxA Rust client in pull requests. (#141) r=eoger

There are a number of changes here.  The most obvious is that we run a
decision task and build a taskgraph for PRs now.  But internally, many
things are ready to generalize to non-FxA Rust Client projects.  The
NDK and Rust toolchains are built into a Docker image (with a very
verbose name!) that is shared with Mentat.  It's nice!  The standalone
toolchains are installed in that image.  The image sets:

ANDROID_NDK_HOME=/build/android-ndk
ANDROID_NDK_API_VERSION=26
ANDROID_NDK_TOOLCHAIN_DIR=/build/android-ndk-toolchain

In $ANDROID_NDK_TOOLCHAIN_DIR the toolchains are named like
$ARCH-$ANDROID_NDK_API_VERSION; this allows to cache multiple versions
of the toolchain (if needed).  So we have, say

/build/android-ndk-toolchain/arm-26
/build/android-ndk-toolchain/arm64-26
/build/android-ndk-toolchain/x86-26

This configuration is what the `rust-android-gradle` plugin expects.
That plugin will be used for the Android Logins API in this repository.

The Dockerfile is in the Mentat repository right now, but I expect it
to migrate to application-services (or even android-components)
eventually.

[sync15/passwords] Update to use the setup state machine.

Split out `m/g` and `c/k` reconciliation into separate functions.

Add doc comments for `SetupStorageClient` and `SetupState`.

Refactor the state machine to use CPS instead of mutating global state.

We now build and pass complete `GlobalState` structs between states,
ensuring we don't accidentally keep dirty state around.
`SetupStateMachine::to_ready` takes the previous `GlobalState` by
value, and returns a new `GlobalState`.

`engine_state_changes` and `engines_that_need_reset` live on
`GlobalState` now, not `SyncStateMachine`.

This also reverts `SetupState` to use string labels instead of
`mem::Discriminant`. Discriminants require an initialized variant, and,
since all the `SetupState` variants carry data now, using
discriminants in `allowed_states` requires initializing the variants
with dummy values.
Use the collection last modified time, not server time, for uploads.

[automation] Use new `libname` rust-android-gradle setting to set ELF SONAME. (Fixes #197)

This is a very different approach to producing Android-friendly
libraries than we followed in
https://github.com/mozilla/application-services/pull/175.  This
commits to always using Gradle to produce Android binaries, rather
than allowing to use Cargo (perhaps without Gradle).  It's a trade
off, and this seems better than requiring local developers to run
`patchelf` manually to test on Android 6.0.
[automation/fxa client] Part 4: Build FxA client AAR rather than ZIP.
[automation/fxa client] Part 3: Add fxa_client Gradle configuration.

[automation/fxa client] Part 2: Build logins on GH 'push' events.

I'm going to overload these tasks to build both the FxA client and the
Sync 1.5 pieces for now; eventually we can split these into multiple
TC tasks.  It's better to keep them together until we split out the
OpenSSL bits into a dependent task first.

[automation/fxa client] Part 1a: Lift Gradle multi-project to top-level.

There are two project layouts possible.  One is that each sub-project
is its own Gradle project with its own copy of the Gradle wrapper,
project configurations, etc.  The other is that there's one
multi-project with sub-Gradle projects.

Generally the multi-project approach, even for decoupled projects, is
simpler.  The `android-components` repository uses it, even though its
projects are very explicitly decoupled in most cases.

[automation/fxa client] Pre: Use newer version of rust-android-gradle.

This isn't strictly necessary, but 0.3.0 splits out
`cargoBuild{X86,Arm,...}` tasks, which makes testing locally much
cheaper.
